articles.headline: China’s Central Bank Hits Brake on Hot Economy
articles.snippet: For the second time in less than five weeks, China’s central bank has moved to limit lending, a step that came earlier than most economists had expected.
articles.abstract: For the second time in less than five weeks, China’s central bank has moved to limit lending, a step that came earlier than most economists had expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  As most countries agonize over how to keep their barely reviving economies growing, China is already looking to slam on the brakes.

articles.headline: China Sees Growth Engine in a Web of Fast Trains
articles.snippet: In China, 42 high-speed rail lines have opened or are set to open by 2012; the U.S. hopes to build its first high-speed line by 2014.
articles.abstract: In China, 42 high-speed rail lines have opened or are set to open by 2012; the U.S. hopes to build its first high-speed line by 2014.
articles.lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China  The world’s largest human migration  the annual crush of Chinese traveling home to celebrate the Lunar New Year, which is this Sunday  is going a little faster this time thanks to a new high-speed rail line.

articles.headline: Afghan Offensive Is New War Model
articles.snippet: After allied troops clear Marja of insurgents, the test will be to keep it clear.
articles.abstract: After allied troops clear Marja of insurgents, the test will be to keep it clear.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  For all the fighting that lies ahead over the next several days, no one doubts that the American and Afghan troops swarming into the Taliban redoubt of Marja will ultimately clear it of insurgents.

articles.headline: Credit Card Limits for Youth Can Be Opportunity for Parents
articles.snippet: Rules that limit access to credit cards until the age of 21 go into effect this month, which is good news and bad for parents.
articles.abstract: Rules that limit access to credit cards until the age of 21 go into effect this month, which is good news and bad for parents.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re having trouble figuring out how to raise financially responsible children, you’ll be thrilled with this news: Congress is stepping in to help you set some limits.

articles.headline: Coalition Troops Storm a Taliban Haven
articles.snippet: An American, British and Afghan force swept into the city of Marja to destroy the insurgency’s largest haven.
articles.abstract: An American, British and Afghan force swept into the city of Marja to destroy the insurgency’s largest haven.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARJA, Afghanistan  Thousands of American, Afghan and British troops attacked the watery Taliban fortress of Marja early Saturday, moving by land and through the air to destroy the insurgency’s largest haven and begin a campaign to reassert the dominance of the Afghan government across a large arc of southern Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers and Dexter Filkins

articles.headline: Looking for a Date? A Site Suggests You Check the Data
articles.snippet: OkCupid uses statistical tools to analyze traffic on its dating site and publishes the insights, such as to look intriguing, not just attractive, in your profile picture.
articles.abstract: OkCupid uses statistical tools to analyze traffic on its dating site and publishes the insights, such as to look intriguing, not just attractive, in your profile picture.
articles.lead_paragraph: Looking for love on an online dating service?

articles.headline: One Grand Deal Too Many Costs Lobbyist His Job
articles.snippet: Billy Tauzin is leaving his $2 million job amid drug makers’ complaints that he bargained away their profits.
articles.abstract: Billy Tauzin is leaving his $2 million job amid drug makers’ complaints that he bargained away their profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After about two dozen years in Congress, Representative Billy Tauzin of Louisiana was after bigger game  the giant, 200-pound whitetail deer that run through the area of south Texas that hunters call the Golden Triangle.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Duff Wilson

articles.headline: Critics Say Google Invades Privacy With New Service
articles.snippet: Google has faced a firestorm of criticism on blogs and Web sites, and it has already been forced to alter some features of Buzz, its new social networking service.
articles.abstract: Google has faced a firestorm of criticism on blogs and Web sites, and it has already been forced to alter some features of Buzz, its new social networking service.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  When Google introduced Buzz  its answer to Facebook and Twitter  it hoped to get the service off to a fast start. New users of Buzz, which was added to Gmail on Tuesday, found themselves with a ready-made network of friends automatically selected by the company based on the people that each user communicated with most frequently through Google’s e-mail and chat services.

articles.headline: Doctors Haunted by Haitians They Couldn’t Help
articles.snippet: Many of the foreign medical workers who initially flew to Haiti are now overwhelmed by their experiences and the limits to what they could do there.
articles.abstract: Many of the foreign medical workers who initially flew to Haiti are now overwhelmed by their experiences and the limits to what they could do there.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The foreign doctors who performed the first amputations after the earthquake used hacksaws. They relied on vodka for sterilization, substituted local numbing for general anesthesia, jury-rigged tourniquets from rubber gloves. Working around the clock in improvised operating rooms, they sacrificed limbs and lost patients to injuries that are no longer supposed to be disabling or deadly.

articles.headline: Japan Calls Hummer H3 Fuel-Efficient
articles.snippet: Starting this week, Japan’s new, looser fuel-efficiency standards for imported cars will provide a subsidy to buyers of the hulking power machines.
articles.abstract: Starting this week, Japan’s new, looser fuel-efficiency standards for imported cars will provide a subsidy to buyers of the hulking power machines.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Hummer and “fuel-efficient” are rarely mentioned in the same breath.

articles.headline: Hype, Money and Cornstarch: What It Takes to Win at Westminster
articles.snippet: To win at the big dog shows, lots of money is needed for professional handlers, groomers and even ad campaigns in publications like Dog News and The Canine Chronicle.
articles.abstract: To win at the big dog shows, lots of money is needed for professional handlers, groomers and even ad campaigns in publications like Dog News and The Canine Chronicle.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore.

articles.headline: In Detroit, Is There Life After the Big 3?
articles.snippet: As parts makers add customers like NASA and solar power companies, they are helping to offset the tens of thousands of lost jobs in the auto industry.
articles.abstract: As parts makers add customers like NASA and solar power companies, they are helping to offset the tens of thousands of lost jobs in the auto industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT

articles.headline: Afghan Attack Gives Marines a Taste of War
articles.snippet: Company K, part of a surge battalion, received a crash course in the Afghan war as it began an assault into the last large Taliban stronghold in Helmand Province.
articles.abstract: Company K, part of a surge battalion, received a crash course in the Afghan war as it began an assault into the last large Taliban stronghold in Helmand Province.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARJA, Afghanistan  The helicopters landed before dawn Saturday in a poppy field beside a row of mud-walled compounds. The Marines ran into the darkness and crouched through the rotor-whipped dust as their aircraft lifted away.

articles.headline: In Black Caucus, a Fund-Raising Powerhouse
articles.snippet: By taking advantage of political finance laws, the Congressional Black Caucus has built a fund-raising juggernaut unlike anything else in town.
articles.abstract: By taking advantage of political finance laws, the Congressional Black Caucus has built a fund-raising juggernaut unlike anything else in town.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When the Congressional Black Caucus wanted to pay off the mortgage on its foundation’s stately 1930s redbrick headquarters on Embassy Row, it turned to a familiar roster of friends: corporate backers like Wal-Mart, AT&T, General Motors, Coca-Cola and Altria, the nation’s largest tobacco company.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Wall St. Helped to Mask Debt Fueling Europe’s Crisis
articles.snippet: Wall Street did not create Europe’s debt problem, but bankers enabled Greece and others to borrow beyond their means, in deals that were perfectly legal.
articles.abstract: Wall Street did not create Europe’s debt problem, but bankers enabled Greece and others to borrow beyond their means, in deals that were perfectly legal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street tactics akin to the ones that fostered subprime mortgages in America have worsened the financial crisis shaking Greece and undermining the euro by enabling European governments to hide their mounting debts.
articles.byline: By Louise Story, Landon Thomas Jr. and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Future Bailouts of America
articles.snippet: Lawmakers don’t want to acknowledge the costs of implicit federal guarantees, but that doesn’t make the costs disappear.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers don’t want to acknowledge the costs of implicit federal guarantees, but that doesn’t make the costs disappear.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS Washington spins its wheels on financial reform, it’s becoming painfully clear that the problem of entities that are too interconnected or “too politically powerful to fail” is also too hard for our policy makers to tackle.

articles.headline: Errant U.S. Rocket Strike Kills Civilians in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Avoiding civilian deaths, which came on the second day of a major allied offensive around Marja, has been a cornerstone of the new U.S. war strategy.
articles.abstract: Avoiding civilian deaths, which came on the second day of a major allied offensive around Marja, has been a cornerstone of the new U.S. war strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARJA, Afghanistan — An errant American rocket strike on Sunday hit a compound crowded with Afghan civilians in the last Taliban stronghold in Helmand Province, killing at least 10 people, including 5 children, military officials said.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers and Rod Nordland

articles.headline: Twists Multiply in Alabama Shooting Case
articles.snippet: The husband of the Alabama neuroscientist confirmed they had been questioned in a 1993 mail bomb plot.
articles.abstract: The husband of the Alabama neuroscientist confirmed they had been questioned in a 1993 mail bomb plot.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala.  On Friday, this city of rocket scientists and brainy inventors was stunned when a neuroscientist with a Harvard Ph.D. was arrested in the shooting deaths of three of her colleagues after she was denied tenure.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Katie Zezima

articles.headline: Inviting In a Brash Outsider
articles.snippet: Vice magazine’s libertarianism and cultural literacy brings to mind Playboy in its prime, mixing nudity with in-depth reports from the world’s most troubled spots.
articles.abstract: Vice magazine’s libertarianism and cultural literacy brings to mind Playboy in its prime, mixing nudity with in-depth reports from the world’s most troubled spots.
articles.lead_paragraph: Visit CNN.com these days and you might come across a video about Liberia in which a regular-looking guy, about as far from a dashing foreign correspondent as you can get, is walking through a swamp and interviewing a Liberian warlord named General Butt Naked. (He’s called that because he leads his fighters wearing nothing more than a bad attitude.)

articles.headline: Cities Prepare for Life With the Electric Car
articles.snippet: In West Coast communities, green consciousness and enthusiasm seem to be stirring public interest in the cars.
articles.abstract: In West Coast communities, green consciousness and enthusiasm seem to be stirring public interest in the cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  If electric cars have any future in the United States, this may be the city where they arrive first.
articles.byline: By Todd Woody and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Politicians as News Analysts Raise Questions on Their Goal
articles.snippet: With some analysts having held elected office and others eying Washington, questions have been raised about their TV commentary turning into campaigning.
articles.abstract: With some analysts having held elected office and others eying Washington, questions have been raised about their TV commentary turning into campaigning.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sarah Palin. Mike Huckabee. Newt Gingrich.

articles.headline: Local TV for Devices on the Move
articles.snippet: Broadcasters that have been losing viewers are betting that TV on mobile devices can win back an audience and lead to new revenue.
articles.abstract: Broadcasters that have been losing viewers are betting that TV on mobile devices can win back an audience and lead to new revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who has time to sit on the couch and watch TV anymore? In the last 10 years, broadcasters have lost 25 percent of their audience. So to win back some viewers, the industry has a plan to grab their attention while they are on the move.

articles.headline: U.S. Housing Aid Winds Down, and Cities Worry
articles.snippet: An Indiana city symbolizes failed efforts to turn around the housing slump at the heart of the credit crisis.
articles.abstract: An Indiana city symbolizes failed efforts to turn around the housing slump at the heart of the credit crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELKHART, Ind.  Over the next six months, the federal government plans to wind down many of its emergency programs for housing. Then it will become clear if the market can function on its own.

articles.headline: Despite Budgets, Some Newsrooms Persist in Costly Fight for Records
articles.snippet: As journalism budgets continue to wither, some companies are taking aggressive action, but other smaller publications have had to let go of those efforts.
articles.abstract: As journalism budgets continue to wither, some companies are taking aggressive action, but other smaller publications have had to let go of those efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last fall Hearst, the big media company that owns newspapers, magazines and television stations, filed a lawsuit against the Texas governor’s office, seeking access to a clemency report in the case of Cameron Todd Willingham, who was executed in 2004 but whose guilt is now in doubt.

articles.headline: Haiti Emerges From Its Shock, and Tears Roll
articles.snippet: After a numb month during which few individuals had ceremonies to mark their deaths, grief is pouring out at memorials and funerals.
articles.abstract: After a numb month during which few individuals had ceremonies to mark their deaths, grief is pouring out at memorials and funerals.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Will anyone remember that 17-year-old Angelania Ritchelle, a parentless high school student who wanted to be a fashion model, died of fright two days after the earthquake and ended up in a mass grave on the outskirts of this city?

articles.headline: After 9/11 Trial Plan, Holder Hones Political Ear
articles.snippet: Once resistant to perceived intrusion by White House political officials, the attorney general now seeks their guidance.
articles.abstract: Once resistant to perceived intrusion by White House political officials, the attorney general now seeks their guidance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Last winter, when Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. called the United States a “nation of cowards” for avoiding frank conversations on race, President Obama mildly rebuked him in public.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Clinton Raises U.S. Concerns of Military Power in Iran
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said that the U.S. feared Iran’s government was being supplanted by the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said that the U.S. feared Iran’s government was being supplanted by the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  The United States fears that Iran is drifting toward a military dictatorship, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Monday, with the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps seizing control of large swaths of Iran’s political, military and economic establishment.

articles.headline: Half of Town’s Taliban Flee or Are Killed, Allies Say
articles.snippet: As heavy fighting in the insurgent stronghold of Marja carried into its third day, the number of Taliban fighters in the area dropped by about half, U.S. and Afghan commanders said.
articles.abstract: As heavy fighting in the insurgent stronghold of Marja carried into its third day, the number of Taliban fighters in the area dropped by about half, U.S. and Afghan commanders said.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAD ALI, Afghanistan  As heavy fighting in the insurgent stronghold of Marja carried into its third day, the number of Taliban fighters in the area has dropped by about half, American and Afghan commanders said Monday.

articles.headline: Microsoft Starts Over in Phone Software
articles.snippet: Microsoft unveiled a new version of its flagship smartphone software, now called Windows Phone.
articles.abstract: Microsoft unveiled a new version of its flagship smartphone software, now called Windows Phone.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain  The frenetic pace of the mobile phone industry has forced some of the technology world’s largest players to make a break with the past.
